content.description: One Ounce Wagyu shines in the morning sun and should be easy to spot if you’re close. It’s 40’ east and a few feet uphill from Gym Jug Thug.Start out on a good right foot and follow the crimps and rail feet directly up. Stay out of the arete crack for a direct slab climb.
content.location: 200 yds of Spicy Meatball and directly north of HWY 49 only 30-50 yds from the road.One Ounce Wagyu sits 40-50’ east of Gym Jug Thug and just uphill.If you’re warming up here no pad is needed but if you’re new to outside bouldering a spotter or small pad would be good.

content.description: TBD Campus is directly beneath and south of One Ounce Wagyu.Start on Mickey-Mouse Ears and campus hang. Work up sharp jugs to top out.Pour one out for your skin.
content.location: About 200 yds east of Spicy Meatball, Grogu Rocks area features a cluster of problems right off of HWY 49.Look for a twisted looking boulder taller than the rest and the boulders are all very close to this rock. One Ounce Wagyu is directly beside it. Gym Jug Thug is 25’ west. The Campus route is directly south 15’.

content.description: Gym Jug Thug should be the first Grogu Rock you find in the area.The great pair of jugs faces east. Hang start from these, establish feet and work up crimps to top-out.  For newer climbers this problem will test lock-off and flagging.
content.location: Hang start from the gym jugs. Gym Jug Thug sits 200 yds east of Spicy Meatball. It is just west and beneath the tall twisted looking boulder you may notice driving in from Medicine Park.

content.description:
Grogu Rocks sit directly north of HWY 49 at the base of Mt Scott. They are a few hundred yards east of Spicy Meatball and can be located by watching for a tall twisted looking boulder sticking out of the tree line. That should be the tallest boulder near the road seen coming west into the Fuge from Medicine Park. 

  Grogu Rocks features a collection of easy access VB-V2 problems and will be a good place for newer climbers to get used to latching onto granite.
